transcription:
1: Dual consonant verbs such as ⲃⲱⲗ
2: Dual consonants verbs that are doubled, ie its second letter is repeated like ϧⲙⲟⲙ 
3: Triple consonants words such as ⲫⲱⲣϣ 
4: Dual words that have a vowel ending such as ⲙⲓⲥⲓ or as he calls them incomplete triple verbs
5: Quadruple consonants words as ⲃⲟⲣⲃⲉⲣ
6: Quintet consonants words such as ⲥⲕⲟⲣⲕⲉⲣ 
7: Quadruple verbs whose last letter is doubled (i forgot the english word) such as ⲥⲟⲃϯ (that was originally "sobd-d")
8: Quadruple verbs that have a vowel ending such as ⲙⲟⲥϯ (that was originally mosd-di")

And in the text bottom of the list he says that many verbs in Ancient Egyptian lost their endings in Coptic but still followed the rules as if they had the same amount of consonants in Ancient Egyptian such as ϣⲱⲡⲓ that was xpr (three consonants) and ⲭⲱ that was koʔ (Two consonants)
Beginning with the dual constant verbs, their formations (as what their vowels are) go as the following
Complete: ⲱ
Incomplete: ⲉ
Pronoun: ⲟ
Qualitative: ⲏ
As in the examples above

Notes:
Dual verbs that begin with ⲙ or ⲛ have their ⲱ vowel in the complete form turned into an ⲟⲩ vowel, as the rule goes thar ⲙ and ⲛ alwayd make the ⲱ an ⲟⲩ such as the verbs ⲙⲟⲩⲛ, ⲛⲟⲩⲧ, ⲙⲟⲩⲣ so their formations become
Complete: ⲟⲩ
Incomplete: ⲉ
Pronoun: ⲟ
Qualitative: ⲏ 
Note 2 is that some dual verbs 
Can end with vowels in their complete forms, like the verb ⲥⲱⲕ which can also be ⲥⲱⲕⲓ 
And there are also dual consonants words that only have one form that ends with a vowel, at least that we know of, such as the verb ⲕⲱϯ

Irregularities: Verbs that end with ϣ ϧ or ϩ 
Before ϣ the incomplete ⲉ alot of time becomes ⲁ or ⲉand the pronoun ⲟ becomes ⲁ or rarely ⲉ 
Before ϧ the pronoun ⲟ always becomes ⲁ
Before ϩ complete ⲱ becomes ⲟ,  ⲉ to ⲁ alot of the time, and often the pronouns ⲟ to an ⲁ, and the qualitative ⲏ to an ⲉ, basically it weekens strong pronouns and turns small pronouns into ⲁ, examples are as follows

Second types of verbs is basically dual verbs that have one of their consonants repeated, those are extremely rare and go as follows
Complete: ⲟ
Incomplete:?
Pronoun:?
Qualitative: ⲏ with the deletion of the first of the 2 identical consonants
As follows

Triple consonants verbs: 
They split to the following
1st kind is for the vowel to follow the first consonant, and for all of thise to be Transitive verbs, and their forms are 
Complete: ⲱ 
Incomplete: ⲉ
Pronoun: ⲟ 
Qualitative: ⲟ 
Just like with the dual consonants, if the first consonant is ⲙ/ⲛ, ⲱ becomes ⲟⲩ 
And the last 2 in this screenshot are dual verbs in coptic, but in ancient Egyptian they had 3 consonants so they follow the 3 consonants formations

Other dual consonants verbs that lost one of their consonants in coptic that end with ⲓ follow the same rule, like ϣⲱⲡⲓ 
And also verbs that end with ⲃ ⲙ or ⲛ that have a second assistant vowel, which stays in Complete Incomplete and Qualitative forms but swaps places with the ⲙ ⲛ or ⲃ so ⲥⲱⲧⲉⲙ becomes ⲥⲟⲑⲙⲉ⳹ or ϧⲱⲧⲉⲃ becomes ϧⲟⲑⲃⲉ⳹(ⲧ became ⲑ because ⲃⲗⲙⲛⲣ aspirate it)
Before ϧ and ϩ the pronoun and qualitative ⲟ becomes an ⲁ again , 
And the incomplete ⲉ to and ⲁ if there is an assistant ⲉ in the end of the verb like ⲑⲱϩⲉⲙ becomes ⲑⲁϩⲉⲙ instead of ⲑⲉϩⲉⲙ 
And the complete ⲱ becomes ⲟ in the verbs ϫⲱⲕϩ/ϫⲟⲕϩ, ϣⲱⲕϩ, and ϣⲱⲛϩ

2: Intransitive verb verbs that have 3 consonants have their formats as the following 
Complete: o
Incomplete: ?
Pronoun:? 
Qualitative: o with switching one the consonat before the ⲟ making it after it (ϩⲗⲟϫ becomes ϩⲟⲗϫ) 
And as said before ϧ ϩ ϣ make the ⲟ an ⲁ so if the triple consonants verb's vowel comes 
Before the last consonant ϧ ϩ or ϣ it is an ⲁ instead of ⲟ, but when switching the consonants and thus changing the letter after the vowel, it returns to an ⲟ (Like ⲙⲕⲁϩ becomes ⲙⲟⲕϩ)
And the opposite if the ϩ ϧ ϣ is in the middle of the word instead such as ⲛϣⲟⲧ=>ⲛⲁϣⲧ 
Irregularities are ϩⲕⲟ=>ϩⲟⲕⲉⲣ
ϭⲣⲟϩ=>ϫⲟⲣϩ and possibly others

Intransitive triple consonants verbs that end with ⲁⲓ have their qualitative forms by flipping the consonant and the last vowel and turning the vowel into an ⲟ such as ⲟⲩϫⲁⲓ=>ⲟⲩⲟϫ 
As for transitive verbs that end with ⲁⲓ their forms are the following
Complete: ⲁⲓ
Incomplete: ⲉ 
Pronoun: ⲏⲧ
Qualitative: ⲏⲟⲩⲧ 
Like the verb ⲥϧⲁⲓ 
Verbs ⲥⲱⲟⲩⲛ and ⲧⲱⲟⲩⲛ are irregulars and are formed as following
Complete: ⲥⲱⲟⲩⲛ/ⲧⲱⲟⲩⲛ
Incomplete:ⲥⲟⲩⲉⲛ/ⲧⲉⲛ
Pronoun:ⲥⲟⲩⲱⲛ/ⲧⲱⲛ
Qualitative: ⲥⲟⲩⲏⲛ/?
And their complete forms are used like pronoun forms if the pronoun is plural 3rd person (they) 
So it is day ⲧⲱⲟⲩⲛⲟⲩ instead of ⲧⲱⲛⲟⲩ

3: Incomplete triple verbs
And those are the verbs that have had 3 consonants and 2 vowels, last vowel being ⲓ, but the last consonant in these verbs that was ⲧ fell and the ⲓ stayed
Like the verb ⲙⲓⲥⲓ was "msit"
Their forms are
 Complete:ⲓ,ⲓ
Incomplete:ⲉ
Pronoun:ⲁ
Qualitative: ⲟ,ⲓ
Before ⲙ ⲛ ⲃ, ⲁ becomes ⲉ  in the qualitative form
And ⲟ becomes ⲁ before ⲕ ϣ ϧ 
Irregularities from this rule are the verbs ⲓⲣⲓ ϩⲓⲟⲩⲓ and ϯ 
Formats being 
Complete:ⲓⲣⲓ/ϯ/ϩⲓⲟⲩⲓ
Incomplete:ⲉⲣ/ϯ/ϩⲓ
Pronoun:ⲁⲓ/ⲧⲏⲓ/ϩⲓⲧ
Qualitative: ⲟⲓ/ⲧⲟⲓ/ϩⲱⲟⲩⲓ

5 and 6, quadruple verbs 
And those follow the same formation 
Complete:ⲟ,ⲉ
Incomplete:ⲉ,ⲉ
Pronoun:ⲉ,ⲱ
Qualitative: ⲉ,ⲱ
Notice that in the following examples all the quadruple and quintet verbs are same syllable just with different vowels, only exception being ⲟⲩⲟⲥⲑⲉⲛ, rule is if the word being repeated in the verb is of 2 syllables, it is doubled with different vowels, if it is of 3 consonants, only the last 2 consonants get doubled with changing vowels
ϩⲱⲛ=>ϩⲟⲛϩⲉⲛ
ⲑⲣⲟϣ=>ⲑⲣⲟϣⲣⲉϣ

5 and 6, quadruple verbs 
And those follow the same formation 
Complete:ⲟ,ⲉ
Incomplete:ⲉ,ⲉ
Pronoun:ⲉ,ⲱ
Qualitative: ⲉ,ⲱ
Notice that in the following examples all the quadruple and quintet verbs are same syllable just with different vowels, only exception being ⲟⲩⲟⲥⲑⲉⲛ, rule is if the word being repeated in the verb is of 2 syllables, it is doubled with different vowels, if it is of 3 consonants, only the last 2 consonants get doubled with changing vowels
ϩⲱⲛ=>ϩⲟⲛϩⲉⲛ
ⲑⲣⲟϣ=>ⲑⲣⲟϣⲣⲉϣ
Image

7,8 Triple consonants with a doubled consonant, triple consonants with a doubled consonant and a vowel end 
Of 7 there is only one verb that is ⲥⲟⲃϯ 
Complete:ⲥⲟⲃϯ
Incomplete:ⲥⲉⲃⲧⲉ
Pronoun:ⲥⲉⲃⲧⲱⲧ
Qualitative: ⲥⲉⲃⲧⲱⲧ
And of the second kind there are some like ⲙⲟⲥϯ and ⲙⲟⲛⲓ 
Complete:ⲟ,ⲓ
Incomplete:ⲉ,ⲉ
Pronoun:ⲉ or ⲁ,ⲱ/ⲟⲩ 
Qualitative: ? (Presumably also ⲱ)
And a summary of everything we said
